Award.AwardTitle: Support for Cyber-Physical Systems Week 2018 Student Participation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal provides travel support for students from educational institutions in the United States to attend the Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) Week 2018 in Porto, Portugal, from 10-13 April 2018. CPS Week is an annual international multi-conference event for the cyber-physical systems researchers. It is the premier event for the global CPS research community where the latest advances in theory and applications are discussed. This year the week-long event hosts four major multi-day conferences, twelve one-day workshops, five one-day tutorials, and three CPS competitions.

CPS is an active and dynamic research area that is rapidly growing. This proposal provides travel for U.S. students to attend CPS Week, which provides a unique opportunity for the students to learn about the state of the science and technology in CPS research. They have the opportunity to attend keynote lectures and presentations, discuss posters with the authors, see demonstrations of advanced CPS technologies and, generally, engage with CPS researcher leaders in academia, industry and government.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this grant was to support and increase student participation in CPSWeek 2018 (Cyber-Physical Systems Week), an event consisting of four conferences, HSCC, ICCPS, IPSN, and RTAS, and around 15 workshops, tutorials, and competitions, held on April 10-13, 2018, in Porto, Portugal.

There were three major goals:

1) Encourage US students to learn from the keynotes, conference talks, posters, and demos on cutting-edge CPS topics, and network with both CPS leaders and other young researchers.

2) Promote the growth of a research community in the fledgling area of CPS. Encourage under-represented students in the CPS area to join this growing scientific community and learn cutting-edge technology in the design and development of next generation CPS.

3) Support activities of ACM/IEEE conferences on CPS, which are the main forum for hosting original, cross-disciplinary research and interactions across embedded systems, hybrid systems, real-time systems, and sensor networks.

We provided travel grants to 17 US based students to partially offset travel (using a US carrier), registration, and hotel accommodation expenses to attend CPSWeek 2018. The travel grants were dispersed in the from of a stipend and did not exceed $1,500 per student. In case expenses were lower than $1,500, students received the amount specified in the provided receipts. Priority was given to students who would not otherwise attend CPSWeek and to increasing participant diversity.

Out of the 17 students that received travel grants, 7 were US citizens, 5 were women, and 1 was from an under-represented group. Only 5 students had attended CPSWeek before and only: 1 student was presenting a (workshop) paper and 2 students were presenting at a tutorial workshop. Hence, we succeeded in attracting students that otherwise would not attend CPSWeek.

In terms of conferences, 9 students attended IPSN, 1 student attended RTAS, and 7 students attended ICCPS. The institutions of the supported students were:

University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (3 students)
Carnegie Mellon University (2 students)
University of California, Berkeley (2 students)
Bucknell University (1 student)
George Washington University (1 student)
University of California Santa Barbara (1 student)
University of Colorado - Boulder (1 student)
University of Michigan (1 student)
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (1 student)
University of Virginia (1 student)

 


Last Modified: 09/14/2018
Modified by: Paulo Tabuada
